subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... But English speakers don t make the distinction between an aspirated and unaspirated P, so it doesn t really matter if the P is aspirated or not. If B is
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
>
>
> Paul Tremblay scripsit:
>
> > But above all this topic really shows the need for a standard mapping of
> > QS letters to IPA symbols. I can see that different people pronounce
> > words differently, but if each QS letter does not mean a very specific
> > sound, which should map to IPA, then the alphabet becomes ambiguous and
> > somewhat meaningless.
>
> Such a mapping is unattainable, because even uncontroversial English
> consonants map to more than one IPA sound depending on dialect and on the
> surrounding sounds. English "p" is an aspirated unvoiced labial stop,
> except after "s" where it loses aspiration; English "b" is an unaspirated
> labial stop, but it can be voiced or voiceless or varying freely between
> the two.
>

But English speakers don't make the distinction between an aspirated and
unaspirated P, so it doesn't really matter if the P is aspirated or not.
If B is not voiced, it is a p, right?

I think you are splitting hairs. You can certainly look up pronociations
in any dictionary. If sounds can't be mapped to IPA, then what do
dictionaries do?

If we can't map QS to IPA, then it is completely meaningless. Certainly,
there is no one way to spell a word. If you are now saying that QS
cannot be mapped to a standard prononciation, then that means I can
spell a word any way I want.

Let me be more specific. If I write "an" as "Ado-Nun," then I need
readers to understand that they are to pronounce this word with two sounds:

1. a vowel that is in the middle of the mouth with the mouth mid open.
(The so-called schwa sound)

2. a n sound (not sure how this is pronounced!)

If we are to say that we cannot map QS to IPA, what is to prevent a
reader from reading this text as:

1. the frontal vowel sound with the mouth open (ae).

2. the n sound.

Is QS to mean anything or is it just a plaything?


Sorry to sound exasperated, but there has to be some agreement so we can
have a guide, especiallly with the vowels. I have wasted needless hours
because the inadequate manual shows you how to pronounce words by giving
examples of words, which is very imprecise and a form of circular
reasoning. Using IPA as a guide would certainly help newcomers and would
probably greatly help clarify things amongst experienced users.

Paul
